title-group.article-title: Exact modeling for control of flexible manipulators

article-meta.aff: Dipartimento di Ingegneria dell’Innovazione, Università del Salento, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Carmelo di Castri, Dipartimento di Ingegneria dell’Innovazione, Università del Salento, 73100 Lecce, Italy Email: carmelo.dicastri@unisalento.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This work presents the dynamic modeling and active vibration control of planar multilink manipulators having flexible links. Since the eigenvalue problem of such continuous structures is strongly dependent on the posture configuration, at first an efficient matrix formulation is provided in order to derive exact natural frequencies and mode shapes of a robot in its general posture. The analytical modal data are used to develop the forced vibration model; this is accomplished through the analytical decoupling of the modal coordinates of the manipulator; to this latter end, orthogonality conditions of modal shapes sets of planar multilink manipulators are demonstrated.

The suppression of vibrations is challenged through a full-state linear quadratic regulator controller by optimally placing collocated sensor/actuator pairs. An optimal stochastic observer is designed in line with the noise-corrupted truncated model, i.e. the continuous Kalman-Bucy filter. The simulation results demonstrate that the presented matrix formulation for deriving exact modal data is effective, and the designed control method, along with the forcedvibration solving strategy, is feasible and efficient.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, the increasing utilization of robotic manipulators in various applications has been motivated by the requirements and demands of industrial automation. Among the rigid and flexible manipulator types, attention is focused more towards flexible manipulators. Flexible manipulator systems offer several advantages in contrast to their traditional rigid counterparts. These include higher motion speeds, higher accuracy in operations, better energy efficiency and lower manipulation cost. These advantages greatly motivate the research in the modeling and control of flexible robots, making flexural dynamics (vibration) the main research challenge and leading research activities in flexible manipulators toward methodologies to cope with the flexural motion dynamics of such systems.

A considerable amount of research on the development of dynamic models of flexible manipulators has been carried out, ranging from a single-link manipulator rotating about a fixed axis to three-dimensional 3multi-link arms. Dwivedy and Eberhard (2006) conducted a comprehensive review of the literature on the dynamic analysis and control of flexible manipulators. They made an effort in order to present a survey of the literature related to flexible robotic manipulators, by reviewing 433 papers published between the years 1974–2005.

Dynamic models of flexible manipulators have been described either by partial differential equations (PDEs) or by finite-dimensional ordinary differential equations (ODEs) through some kind of approximation. A commonly used approach for solving a PDE that represents the dynamics of a manipulator, sometimes referred to as the separation of variables method, is to utilize a representation of the PDE, obtained through a simplification process, by a finite set of ordinary differential equations. The most commonly used methods include the assumed-modes method (AMM) and finite element (FE) method.

In the AMM, the elastic deflection of the beam is represented by an infinite number of separable modes. Since the low-frequency modes are dominant in the system’s dynamics, the modes are truncated to a finite number to obtain a system with a finite dimensionality. Bellezza et al. (1990) found the exact eigenfunctions of a slewing flexible link with a rotating inertia at the base and a payload at the tip and experimentally validated the theoretical results. De Luca and Siciliano (1991) presented the closed-form equations for planar lightweight manipulators with multiple flexible links modeled as Euler-Bernoulli beams with proper clamped-mass boundary conditions. Yu and Elbestawi (1995) derived a comprehensive dynamic model of two link planar flexible manipulator with both the links and joints considered to be flexible and no assumptions of small joint angle motions. Finally, Chen (2001) established a linearized dynamic model for a general planar multilink flexible manipulator by decomposing the motion of each link as the nonlinear gross rigid-body motion upon which vibrations are superimposed.

In the FE method the flexible beam is divided into a finite number of elements, and elastic deformation of the link is represented in the form of a linear combination of admissible functions and generalized coordinates. There are many kinds of admissible functions to be selected. Actually, any function that meets boundary conditionsof certain nodes can be applied. Al-Bedoor and Almusallam (2000) presented a dynamic model of a rotating flexible link driven through a flexible joint, accounting for thegravitational and axial shortening effects and the dynamics of a payload having rotary inertia. Farid and Lukasiewicz (2000) proposed a Lagrangian/FE approach for the dynamic modeling of lightweight multilink spatial manipulators with flexible links and joints; the proposed dynamic model is free from the assumption of a nominal motion and takes into account the coupling effect among the rigid body motion of the system, the bending and torsional deflections of the links, and the flexibility of the joints. Fotouhi (2007) studied the vibration analysis of very flexible beams with a large deflection using the FE approach. Comparisons with the responses of similar models of published works showed that FE analysis is a reliableapproach and can produce acceptable results for the large amplitude vibration analysis of very flexible beams. Finally, Abedi et al. (2008) investigated modeling and vibrations of a two link flexible manipulator, using the FE method to model the flexible deformation of the links. The rigid-body motion and elastic deformation were decoupled by linearizing the equations of motion around the rigid-body reference trajectory.

Therefore, several models and methods of analysis have been researched for the dynamic characterization of flexible manipulators and, accordingly, simulation algorithms characterizing the dynamic behavior of such systems have been developed in order to provide the means of analysis and verification of control techniques. The control problem for flexible robot manipulators belongs to the class of mechanical systems where the number of control variables is strictly less than the number of mechanical degrees of freedom. The desired control task can be assigned at the joint level as if the manipulator were rigid and provided that link deformation is kept limited, satisfactory results may also be obtained for the end-effector motion.

On the basis of a truncated model obtained from either the AMM or FE method, various control approaches can be applied. Mohamed and Tokhi (2004) developed feed-forward control strategies for the vibration control of a planar single-link flexible manipulator using input shaping, low-pass and band-stop filtered input techniques The FE method was considered for obtaining the dynamic model of the flexible manipulators. Yang et al. (2001) considered the problem of tip trajectory tracking control for a multilink flexible manipulator. The Lagrangian AMM was used to derive the dynamic model of the manipulator and an integrated optical laser sensor system was employed to measure deformations; an error compensation approach was presented to improve the tracking/positioning accuracy. Subudhi and Morris (2002) presented a dynamic modeling technique for a manipulator with multiple flexible links and flexible joints, based on the AMM, and two-time-scale singularly perturbed model. Then, a controller was designed for the tracking and control of link and joint vibrations, based on the two-time-scale separation of the flexible link and flexible joint manipulator dynamics. Green and Sasiadek (2004) faced the tracking control problem of a two-link robot manipulator. They used a rigid dynamics model and proportional-derivative (PD) gains computed on dominant cantilever and pinned–pinned assumed mode frequencies by three different techniques: inverse dynamics, linear quadratic regulator (LQR), and fuzzy logic. Their investigations showed how fuzzy logic produces the best result for the cantilever mode and LQR for the pinned–pinned mode.

The abovementioned works deal with traditional flexible manipulators, which usually have only one motor for each link acting as an actuator; because the system is an infinite dimension, some kind of difficulty can arise when the controller design is performed. Accordingly, an alternative way to solve the control problem of flexible-link manipulators has been proposed through the use of piezoelectric materials, which can be bonded/embedded along a beam to achieve transformation between mechanical deformation and electrical field and can be used as actuators and sensors. While the resulting system retains all the advantages of the conventional flexible robots, such as dexterity, lightweight, high speed motion and safety, it has additional sensing and control capabilities. Moreover, it is expected that a better control performance for flexible robots will be easily obtained with the application of smart materials.

To this latter end, some interesting works have been carried out on both the modeling and controller design of smart material beams and manipulators. Qiu et al. (2009) investigated the active vibration control of a cantilever beam with bonded piezoelectric patches. Acceleration sensor based proportional feedback control and sliding mode variable structure control algorithms were used to actively control the vibration of a beam, and its stability was theoretically analyzed and experimentally verified. Sun et al. (2004) presented a new approach for the control of a single-link flexible manipulator by using piezoelectric material. Rigid body motion and vibrations were controlled by a combined scheme of PD feedback and command voltages applied to segmented lead zirconate titanate (PZT) actuators bonded to the surface of the flexible link whose placement was opportunely chosen. The PZT actuator control employs linear velocity feedback. Simulation and experimental results confirmed the proposed approach. Shin and Choi (2001) proposed a hybrid control algorithm for the end-point position control of a two-link flexible manipulator featuring piezoelectric actuators and sensors; both regulating and tracking control of the manipulator were realized. Experiments showed that a substantial reduction of unwanted oscillations at the tip of the structure is achieved by activating the piezoactuators during the motion.

Although the tracking control problem of flexible manipulators is nowadays a very topical and interesting basic theme for designers and researchers in the field of robotics, great attention must also be dedicated to the point-to-point position control (PPC) or regulation, where the main task is to suppress vibrations once thedesired manipulator posture has been reached. Tothe best of the authors knowledge, previous studies in the literature did not deal with the active PPC of a planar multilink manipulator based on precise modeling of vibrations in the flexible structure, which is the fundamental step towards sophisticated vibration control.

As described above, the vibrations of links in most of the flexible robots have been modeled by the assumed mode solutions of each flexible link, whilst in an accuratemodeling, the assumed mode expansion up to finite numbers may fail to describe a real vibration in a wide range of configurations due to inexact boundary conditions and discontinuity at the interconnection of flexible links. Therefore, in order to reduce numerical and/or analytical approximations, this paper aims at introducing exact analytical models.

Namely, in this paper, a complete self-contained scheme for modeling and analysis of flexible planar multilink manipulators, complemented with active control, is developed. Firstly, the system mode analysis of a flexible robotic structure having an arbitrary number of links modeled as Euler-Bernoulli beams is proposed. For the analysis, a set of PDEs depending on manipulator configuration are obtained by matching geometrical and dynamical boundary conditions at the rotary joints. A closed-form block matrix formulation describing the differential eigenproblem is derived in order to predict exact system modal frequencies and mode shapes for the chosen posture, without recurring to any kind of special-purpose solver. Once the problem of free vibrations has been addressed, the general forced vibration problem for the multilink manipulator is formulated; the calculation of the forced vibratory response is based on the preliminary knowledge of the vibration modes and can be obtained by the method of modal decomposition. This method is general and makes it possible to treat all types of forces: local or distributed, permanent or transitory. The amplitude associated with each vibration mode is the solution of the modal equation, i.e. the equation of a system with a degree-of-freedom, characterized by a generalized mass, a generalized stiffness and a generalized force. The difficulties of calculation lie in the determination of these generalized quantities in the non-simple case of a multilink manipulator, in particular when the boundary conditions do not conform to the traditional cases.

In order to effectively and actively control the undesired vibrations of the robotic structure, the vibration suppression strategy is based on optimal modal control of a set of significant modes, while state estimation for the stochastic case is also employed. Then, the linear quadratic Gaussian (LQG) controller associated with the LQR and Kalman-Bucy filter (KBF) is formulated by considering the modal state space representation of the vibration control problem. The control model assumes that collocated sensor/actuator pairs, which can represent the use of piezoelectric pairs, are used by the active control algorithm; a strategy of determining the optimal location of the sensor/actuator pairs in active vibration control of the multilink flexible manipulator is proposed in this paper. Moreover, the spillover phenomenon is pointed out and a method for spillover reduction is suggested. Numerical simulations show the validity and effectiveness of the proposed analysis, modeling and control method.

The outline of this paper is as follows: modeling and notation necessary for subsequent development are described in Section 2. Section 3 is devoted to the posture-dependent modal analysis of the manipulator. The forced vibration problem and the active control strategy are described in Sections 4 and 5, respectively, whilst numerical results related to the case studies are given in Section 6. Finally, conclusions are presented in Section 7.

sec.title: 2. Modeling
sec.p:
Let us consider a planar multilink flexible robot which is operated in the horizontal plane with the effect of gravity being ignored. The geometry of the robot is shown in Figure 1 in the undeformed case. The flexible links are assumed to be thin and uniform with a constant cross-section, and satisfy the Euler-Bernoulli beam assumptions of small shear and rotary inertia effects. A local two-dimensional co-ordinate system is assigned to each link and the co-ordinate’s origin is located at the link’s driving rigid joint. The n links are connected by n actuators having mass Mi and inertia Ji, i=1, 2,…, n; actuator 1 is located at the origin of the frame O1X1Y1. The remaining actuators are movable. The free tip of the last link has a concentrated mass payload attached, represented by mass MP and inertia JP. Figure 1.
Multilink flexible manipulator and adopted notation.

There are n frames in total which describe the system, i.e. OiXiYi. All the frames are local reference frames attached to each link at the corresponding joints when the manipulator is at rest, but the initial placement of the frames holds on even when vibrations occur. The deformation of each link with respect to its local co-ordinate is denoted by ui(xi,t) and vi(xi,t), which represent the axial and transverse elastic displacements of the link from the undeformed shape at position xi. The angular position of the ith link with respect to the link i-1 is represented by the joint variable θi.

Now, the adopted conventions allow the performance of the system mode analysis of the multilink manipulator, conversely from previous works where component mode descriptions were employed. It should be remembered that the advantage of the component modes is that they can be solved easily or simply obtained from engineering handbooks. The disadvantage is that they are liable to give inaccurate composite modes. On the other hand, complex structures vibrate with system mode characteristics, rather than a series of component modes and then the system mode description is much better in obtaining more accurate vibration modes even if it is a little complicated to formulate and solve.

According to the elementary beam theory (Meirovitch, 1986), the free-vibration elastic behavior of the link i can be described by the following PDEs: (1)EiSi∂2ui(xi,t)∂xi 2-mi∂2ui(xi,t)∂t2=0 (2)EiIi∂4vi(xi,t)∂xi 4+mi∂2vi(xi,t)∂t2=0 where the first equation represents the axial vibration of the link, and the second equation represents its bending vibration; moreover, Ei is the Young’s modulus of the link, Si the cross-sectional area, Ii the area moment of inertia of link cross-section and mi the mass per unit length. Each link has length Li.

The stress-displacement relations are given by the following equations: (3)Bi(xi,t)=EiIi∂2vi(xi,t)∂xi 2 (4)Ti(xi,t)=-EiIi∂3vi(xi,t)∂xi 3 (5)Ni(xi,t)=EiSi∂ui(xi,t)∂xi where Bi(xi,t) is the bending moment of the ith link, Ti(xi,t) the transverse shear force and Ni(xi,t) the axial force.

Since the modal analysis is based on small perturbations about a nominal configuration, the contribution of the rigid-body motion is neglected and the boundary conditions are obtained from the geometric and natural constraints (Figure 2). Figure 2.
Forces and moments at boundaries.

At x1 = 0: the rotary joint 1 is assumed clamped, sothat the following three geometric constraints are valid: (6)u1(0,t)=v1(0,t)= ∂v1(x1,t)∂x1|x1 = 0=0 At xi = Li or xi+1 = 0, i = 1, 2, …, n - 1 (7) ∂vi(xi,t)∂xi|xi=Li- ∂vi+1(xi+1,t)∂xi+1|xi+1= 0=0 (8) (9) (10) (11) EiIi∂3vi(xi,t)∂xi 3|xi = Li -Mi+1 ∂2vi(xi,t)∂t2|xi = Li + Ei+1Si+1∂ui+1(xi+1,t)∂xi+1|xi+1 = 0sinθi+1 - Ei+1Ii+1∂3vi+1(xi+1,t)∂xi+1 3|xi+1 = 0cosθi+1=0 (12)- EiSi∂ui(xi,t)∂xi|xi = Li-Mi+1 ∂2ui(xi,t)∂t2|xi = Li+ Ei+1Si+1∂ui+1(xi+1,t)∂xi+1|xi+1 = 0cosθi+1+ Ei+1Ii+1∂3vi+1(xi+1,t)∂xi+1 3|xi+1 = 0sinθi+1=0 where the first three equations come from the compatibility of displacements and continuity of rotation, and the last three from the natural boundary conditions, i.e., the bending moment, shear force, and axial force balances. (13)At xn=Ln EnIn∂2vn(xn,t)∂xn 2|xn = Ln+JP ∂3vn(xn,t)∂xn∂t2|xn = Ln=0 (14) EnSn∂un(xn,t)∂xn|xn = Ln+MP ∂2un(xn,t)∂t2|xn = Ln=0 (15) -EnIn∂3vn(xn,t)∂xn 3|xn = Ln+MP ∂2vn(xn,t)∂t2|xn=Ln=0 where the first equation is the moment balance, the second is the axial force balance and the third is the shear force balance at the end-effector.

sec.title: 3. Modal analysis
sec.p: Even if dynamic equations (1) and (2) are decoupled, the above boundary conditions make the axial and bending vibrations dependent on each other. So, when performing system mode analysis of the multilink manipulator, vibration modes are solved together by combining all the conditions, and each modal time function is the common solution of all the axial and bending vibrations and represents the system mode of the whole system.

According to vibration theory, elastic solutions to equations (1) and (2) can be written as (16)ui(xi,t)=Ui(xi)exp(ιωt) (17)vi(xi,t)=Vi(xi)exp(ιωt) where ι is the imaginary unit, ω is the natural frequency of the system mode, Ui(xi) and Vi(xi) are the spatial components of the general separation of variable solutions.

Substituting equations (16) and (17) into equations (1) and (2), the spatial solutions of axial and bending vibration can be determined by the ordinary differential equations such that (18)Ui ″(xi)+αi 2Ui(xi)=0 (19)Vi IV(xi)-βi 4Vi(xi)=0 where αi2 = miω2/EiSi and βi4 = miω2/EiIi.
The general forms of the solutions of equations (18) and (19) are given by (20)Ui(xi)=Ai1cos(αixi)+Ai2sin(αixi) (21)
Moreover, using equations (16) and (17) into boundary conditions, it is possible to rewrite them in terms of spatial functions, i.e. the eigenfunctions Ui(xi) and Vi(xi).

Now, if the spatial solutions in equations (20) and (21) are used, the resulting set of linear homogeneous equations can be written in a linear matrix equation as (22)M(ω)c=0 where (23)c= [A11A12B11B12B13B14…Ai1Ai2Bi1Bi2Bi3Bi4…An1An2Bn1Bn2Bn3Bn4]T

is the 6 × n vector of undetermined modal coefficients, whereas (24) is a square matrix of order 6 × n which represents the system characteristic matrix associated with the chosen posture of the multilink manipulator. M(ω) is a block matrix partitioned as in equation (24); in particular, MO1(ω) e MOEE(ω) are blocks corresponding to the boundary conditions (6) and (13) to (15), respectively, which have been formulated for the rotary joint 1 and the end-effector.

MOi,i(ω) and MOi.i+1(ω) represent the six boundary conditions (7) to (12) for each rotary joint between the link i and the link i + 1. This partitioning procedure is based on a modular description so that the addition or the elimination of one link is equivalent to adding or deleting its corresponding pair of blocks into the system characteristic matrix. The blocks of M(ω) are explicitly reported in Appendix A.
The natural frequencies (or eigenvalues) of the whole system can be determined from the frequency equation given by (25)det[M(ω)]=0

at the non-trivial solutions of the modal vectors c. A denumerable infinite number of roots ωj (j = 1,2…) will be found and, for solutions either symbolically or numerically computed of the equation (25), non-trivial eigenvectors c will be obtained in the null space of M(ω); these vectors will determine the jth system mode shapes of the manipulator through the axial and bending eigenfunctions Uij(xi) and Vij(xi), i.e., the jth system mode shape components for link i.

sec.title: 4. Forced vibrations
sec.p: The dynamics of the ith link, subjected to an arbitrary distributed axial loading pi(xi,t) and to an arbitrary distributed transverse loading qi(xi,t), can be represented by the equations (26)EiSi∂2ui(xi,t)∂xi 2-mi∂2ui(xi,t)∂t2=-pi(xi,t) (27)EiIi∂4vi(xi,t)∂xi 4+mi∂2vi(xi,t)∂t2=qi(xi,t) For the above general forced problem, the solutions can be assumed in the form (28)ui(xi,t)=∑j=1 ∞Uij(xi)gj(t) (29)vi(xi,t)=∑j=1 ∞Vij(xi)gj(t) where Uij(xi) and Vij(xi) are the known eigenfunctions and gj(t) are the unknown modal coordinates.

In order to solve the problem, the amplitudes gj(t) need to be calculated, also by using the orthogonality relations. By imposing all the boundary conditions on the governing equations of the free-vibration problem, the following orthogonality relations are derived:
First orthogonality condition (30)
Second orthogonality condition (31)
Appendix B reports the related proofs of equations (30) and (31).
Now, let the following quantities be denoted as
1) generalized mass MGj of the mode j: (32)
2) generalized stiffness KGj of the mode j: (33)
3) generalized force FGj(t) of the mode j: (34)

The key to the solution of the forced vibration problem of the multilink manipulator consists of uncoupling the modes by using the orthogonality conditions (30) and (31); the dynamics of the jth modal coordinate can be expressed through the generalized terms (32) to (34) as (35)MGjg··j(t)+KGjgj(t)=FGj(t)
The proof is reported in Appendix C.

Equation (35) is the modal equation associated to the mode j; its solution will provide the unknown for the gj(t) problem. The remarkable point is that this equation is that of a system vibrating with one degree-of-freedom,
has the same normal angular frequency as the vibration mode studied.

sec.title: 5. Vibration control
sec.p: When excited, a structure presents preferable modes ofvibration which depend on the spectral content of the excitation. Assuming that the lower order modes, which are the most easily excitable ones, are the most significant to the global response of the system, a truncated modal model of the manipulator can be utilized for the control problem.

The dynamics of the reduced modal space can be expressed as (36)MGg··(t)+KGg(t)=FG(t) where g(t)=[g1(t),g2(t),…,gm(t)]T with m < ∞ thetotal number of modes to be controlled, MG=diag([MG1,MG2,…,MGm]), KG=diag([KG1,KG2,…,KGm]) and FG(t)=[FG1(t),FG2(t),…,FGm(t)]T, with diag(·) denoting diagonal matrices with the individual elements MGj and KGj,j=1,2,…,m. Moreover, it is convenient to write FG(t)=FGext(t)+FGctrl(t), where FGext(t) is due to external forces acting on the robotic structure and FGctrl(t) is due to the control forces applied by actuators.

The state space approach is the basis of the modern control theories; in this method, dynamic systems are described by a set of first-order differential equations in variables called the state. The ultimate aim of the feedback control is often to reduce the motion of the mechanical system to the greatest possible extent and, in that case, the control system is said to act as a regulator. Systems where direct methods of designing feedback control systems which achieve the greatest possible reduction in the dynamic response are used are known as optimal control systems. In this work, an LQG controller, consisting of an LQR and a KBF, is adopted to control the vibration of the structural system.

The dynamical model (36), adjoined with plant and measurement noise w(t) and v(t), can be expressed in state-space form as (37)η·(t)=Aη(t)+Bextuext(t)+Bctrluctrl(t)+w(t) (38)y(t)=Cη(t)+v(t) where η(t)=[g(t)g·(t)]Tis the state vector, A is the system matrix, Bctrl is the control matrix, Bext is the external disturbance matrix, C is the output matrix, uctrl(t) is the control input vector, uext(t) is the external disturbance input vector and y(t) is the output vector. The plant and measurement noise are both assumed to be white, have a Gaussian probability density function and are assumed uncorrelated with the inputs. The correlation properties of the plant and measurement noise vectors are given by the correlation matrices (39)E[w(t)wT(t)]=W; E[v(t)vT(t)]=V

Now, the active control on the structure will be conveniently based on m single collocated sensor/actuator pairs (Meirovitch, 1983), leading the control matrix Bctrl and the output matrix C to be 2 m × m matrix and m × 2 m matrices respectively, whilst uctrl(t) and y(t) vectors of m control inputs and a m outputs. Moreover, the sensor/actuator pairs will be assumed to behave as ideal piezoelectric pairs, i.e. acting on the manipulator as concentrated moments and measuring the rotations of the links where are placed.

Finally, it must be noted that Bctrl, Bext and C are location-dependent matrices, depending on the positions on the robotic structure of external disturbances, sensors and actuators; in particular, Bctrl ≡ Bctrl(x_opt) and C ≡ C(x_opt), where x_opt=[(lp1,p1)(lp2,p2)…(lpm,pm)] is the vector of optimal locations (to be chosen) on the robotic structure where the sensor/actuator pairs are placed; lpk and pk (k = 1…m) are respectively the link and the position on it where the kth sensor/actuator pair is collocated.
The matrices A, Bctrl and C of equations (37) and (38) are then given by (40) whilst Bext depends on the number, the type and the location of the external disturbances applied.

Since the control objective is to attenuate unwanted vibration of the flexible structural system, the performance index (J) to be minimized is given by (Hendricks et al., 2008) (41)J=E{∫0 ∞{ηT(t)Qη(t)+uctrl T(t)Ructrl(t)}dt}
In the above, Q is the state weighting semi-positive matrix and R is the input weighting positive constant.

By the separation theorem, the solution of the formulated problem is given as (42)uctrl(t)=-Kη∧(t) (43)∧·η(t)=Aη∧(t)+Bctrluctrl(t)+L[Cη0(t)+v(t)-Cη∧(t)] where K = R-1BTctrl P∞ is the optimal feedback gain, solution of the LQR problem, with P∞ steady-state solution of the matrix Riccati equation, and η∧(t) is the reconstructed state obtained from the KBF, being L = MCTV-1 the known steady-state Kalman–Bucy gain matrix and M the covariance matrix of the optimal observer.

Since it has been assumed that the random perturbations (force disturbance or measurement noise) are Gaussian, this control philosophy, obtained combining the steady-state KBF with the steady-state LQR, is called LQG control (see Figure 3). Figure 3.
Block diagram of the linear quadratic Gaussian control system.

Now, in the matter of the problem of determining the optimal placements x_opt of the collocated sensor/actuator pairs, it must be noted that for LGQ control the minimum value of the performance index is given by (44)Jopt(ξ)=tr[P∞(ξ)L(ξ)VLT(ξ)+M(ξ)Q] where tr represents the trace and ξ represents the locations of the sensor/actuator pairs. To find the optimal locations x_opt of the sensor/actuator pairs, one has to minimize the Jopt(ξ) given in equation (44) with respect to the all the locations of the multilink manipulator, i.e. the optimal placement problem of the sensor/actuator pairs can be stated as find x_opt: (45)minξ∈⋃i=1 nxi Jopt(ξ)

sec.title: 5.1. Spillover phenomenon
sec.p: The state-space form (37) and (38) represents a reduced model of the flexible manipulator including only the few dominant m low frequency modes. Because of the inherent low damping of flexible structures, there is a danger that the state feedback based on a reduced model destabilizes the residual modes, which are not included in the model of the structure, leading to spillover instability (Balas, 1978).

Although they are not included in the state feedback, the residual modes are excited by the control input and they also contribute to the output measurement. By adopting the subscript c for the controlled modes and the subscript r for the residual modes, the dynamics of the open-loop system is (46)η·c(t)=Acηc(t)+Bc_extuext(t)+Bc_ctrluctrl(t)+w(t) (47)η·r(t)=Arηr(t)+Br_extuext(t)+Br_ctrluctrl(t) (48)y(t)=Ccηc(t)+Crηr(t)+v(t)

Spillover phenomenon arises from the excitation of the residual modes by external sources (external spillover, Br_extuext), by the control (control spillover, Br_ctrluctrl) and the contamination of the sensor output by the residual modes (observation spillover, Crηr). When external spillover occurs, in order to control its effect, unstable residual modes must be included in the reduced system definition In this regard, an interesting recent work dealing with the independent modal control of flexible structures, shows how instabilities due to spillover can lead to significant discrepancies between numerical and experimental results (Resta et al., 2010). Control and observation spillover can instead be reduced by an appropriate design of the regulator and the KBF.

Control spillover can be attenuated by modifying the cost functional (41) used in the regulator design; in particular, a quadratic term BTr_ctrlBr_ctrl is added to the input weighting matrix R, so that the excitation favorable to residual modes is penalized, i.e. the control tends to be orthogonal to residual modes.
Similarly, observation spillover can be reduced by designing the observer as a KBF with a measurement noise matrix V + CTrCr which tends to desensitize the reconstructed states to the residual modes.

sec.title: 6. Numerical studies
sec.p: In this Section the theoretical formulations presented above are utilized to calculate the natural frequencies and corresponding mode shapes of flexible manipulators, and to evaluate the active vibration control results with the collocated sensor/actuator pair, placed according to the index (50).The case studies illustrate how solutions for two-link, three-link and four-link robotic structures can be accurately obtained, when some postures, by way of example, are chosen for investigation; any other posture can be analyzed without restrictions. Numerical simulations are carried out through MATLAB® (The MathWorks™, 2007) code implementation of the relations presented in the sections 3, 4 and 5.

For simplicity, all the links and concentrated masses and inertias for actuators and payload, are assumed to be equal; the numerical values applied to the robot models are summarized in Table 1. Table 1.
Physical parameters
Parameters Symbol (i = 1…n) Value
Length of link Li 5 e–1 m
Mass of actuator Mi 1 e–1 kg
Inertia of actuator Ji 1 e–4 kg·m2
Mass of payload MP 1 e–1 kg
Inertia of payload JP 1 e–4 kg·m2
Cross-sectional area of link Si 2 e–4 m2
Area moment of inertia of link Ii 1.6667 e–9 m4
Young’s modulus of link Ei 70e9 N/m2
Mass per unit length of link mi 4.8 e–1 kg/m

sec.title: 6.1. System mode analysis
sec.p:
Assuming cantilevered conditions at joint 1, the first three natural frequencies and mode shapes are reported in Tables 2, 3 and 4 at various configurations for the two-link, three-link and four-link structure respectively. In particular, two postures for each kind of manipulator are studied; Table 2 reports the predicted modal data for the two-link flexible manipulator when joint 2 is blocked at θ2 = 45° and θ2 = 90°. Table 3 represents the three-link robot with blocked joints 2 and 3 at [θ2 θ3] = [−30° 60°] and [θ2 θ3] = [45° −45°], whilst Table 4 concerns the four-link robotic system when [θ2 θ3 θ4] = [45° −60° 90°] and [θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° −90° −90°]. It must be stressed that the choice of such postures is through-and-through random, only for demonstrative purposes; evidently, every possible joint configuration, belonging to the joint space of the manipulators, can be selected. Table 2.
Modal data for the two-link flexible manipulator
Table 3.
Modal data for the three-link flexible manipulator

For each mode and posture, tables report the analytical natural frequencies (denoted by Present Work solution (PW)), predicted through the code implementation of characteristic matrix (24); the solution of equation (25), and the analytical system mode shapes, which are plotted once the modal vector c of expression (23) is calculated and system mode eigenfunctions Uij(xi) and Vij(xi) can be derived through relations (20) and (21).

Moreover, to verify the system mode analysis, modal tests on FE models of the flexible manipulator have been performed. The commercial FE package ABAQUS V6.6 (Simulia, 2006) has been employed for eigenvalue extraction aimed at computing the natural frequencies for each case study. The FE solutions are reported in the tables along with the analytical ones (PW), and are denoted by FE; such FE solutions correspond to a mesh resulting from a priori convergence analysis on the structural models and show an absolute agreement with those of the present work.Therefore, the FE analysis allows to verify the accuracy of the solutions and to validate the exact formulation of the posture-dependent eigenvalue problem proposed in Section 3.

Finally, it is stressed that the main effort of this work is to provide a tool which allows direct code implementation of exact formulations in order to achieve the best solutions, so as to avoid recurring to special-purpose software packages and numerical convergence analyses.

sec.title: 6.2. Vibration control
sec.p: In order to evaluate the vibration control performanceof the control strategy proposed in Section 5, the dynamic model of the manipulator using the first five modes is considered. The active controller is implemented to control the dynamics of the first three modes of the above tables (m = 3), for each robotic structure (two-, three- and four-link) and for each analyzed posture. The remaining two modes (the fourth and the fifth modes) are treated as residual modes.

Since the modes to be controlled are three, the active controller is represented by three sensor/actuator pairs, placed on the robotic structure according to the optimization criterion (45).Table 5 reports the optimal locations found for each case study. Table 4.
Modal data for the four-link flexible manipulator
Table 5.
Optimal locations for sensor/actuator (s/a) pairs
Posture s/a #1 s/a #2 s/a #3
2-link θ2 = 45° lp1:1 – p1:0.45 lp2:2 – p2:0.25 lp3:2 – p3:0.45
θ2 = 90° lp1:1 – p1:0.25 lp2:2 – p2:0.20 lp3:2 – p3:0.40
3-link [θ2 θ3] = [−30° 60°] lp1:1 – p1:0.25 lp2:2 – p2:0.30 lp3:3 – p3:0.45
[θ2 θ3] = [45° −45°] lp1:1 – p1:0.25 lp2:2 – p2:0.25 lp3:3 – p3:0.45
4-link [θ2 θ3 θ4] = [45° −60° 90°] lp1:2 – p1:0.15 lp2:3 – p2:0.25 lp3:4 – p3:0.45
[θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° −90° −90°] lp1:2 – p1:0.40 lp2:3 – p2:0.45 lp3:4 – p3:0.45
lpk = link where the kth sensor/actuator pair is placed– pk = position on link lpk [m], k = 1,2,3.

Simulations are carried out by separately exciting the two-link, three-link and four-link flexible manipulators by two types of external disturbance: a unitary transverse load force, concentrated at the tip of the first link (L1) and a unitary concentrated moment on the middle of the second link (L2/2); both disturbances are characterized by a Heaviside step function time evolution.

The external disturbance matrices Bc_ext, related to the controlled system (46), are then given by (49)Bc_ext (1)=MG -1[03×37ptV11(L1)7ptV12(L1)7ptV13(L1)] Bc_ext (2)=MG -1[03×35ptV 21 '(L2/2)7ptV 22 '(L2/2)7ptV 23 '(L2/2)] where superscripts (1) and (2) refer respectively to the concentrated force (EX1) and concentrated moment (EX2) excitations.

For all the following cases where the vibration control strategy is applied state weighting and output matrices Q = diag(Ω, I3x3) and R = I3x3 are utilized, where Ω is the diagonal matrix with the generic term ωj2 (squared natural frequency of the jth mode). For the LQG controller design, matrices W = 0.1I6x6 and V = 0.001I3x3 are considered for the definition of the noise correlation matrices and Kalman-Bucy gain design.

Figures 4 to 15 show the control effects on the robotic structures by evaluating the open- and closed-loop transverse tip displacements vn(Ln,t) and control input moments. The thinner line represents the open-loop response when the disturbance force is applied and the system is uncontrolled, whilst the thicker line refers to the controlled response. It can be seen that all the control systems manage to reduce the tip displacement significantly. When compared to the open-loop response, the closed-loop response demonstrates the vibration control efficiency. Figure 4.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator (θ2 = 45° − EX1).

Each figure reports the end-effector displacements onthe top and the control efforts on the bottom. For example, Figure 4 represents the case of a two-link manipulator when θ2 = 45° is subjected to the external excitation EX1 (force applied at the tip of link 1). The figure shows the vibration suppression compared with the open-loop response, and the three control moments due to the collocated sensor/actuator pairs. Figure 5 reports the same analysis for the same robotic structure and posture but when an external moment is applied on the middle of link 2 (excitation EX2). Figures 6 and 7 show results for the posture θ2 = 90°, whilst Figures 8 to 11 and Figures 9 to 15 respectively concern the postures of Table 3 for the three-link manipulator and Table 4 for the four-link manipulator. Figure 5.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator (θ2 = 45° − EX2). Figure 6.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator (θ2 = 90° − EX1). Figure 7.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator (θ2 = 90° − EX2). Figure 8.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3] = [−30° 60°] − EX1). Figure 9.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3] = [−30° 60°] − EX2). Figure 10.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3] = [45° −45°] − EX1). Figure 11.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3] = [45° −45°] −EX2).

In summary, a successful control strategy appears to be associated with the proposed optimal placement of the three collocated sensor/actuator pairs. For different kinds of robotic structures (two-, three- and four-link manipulator) and for different postures (any desired), significant suppression of unwanted vibrations for the overall system can be achieved and, in particular, for the end-effector, where the operative task is usually assigned. Compared to ideal LQR implementations, where a major limitation exists because all the states must be measured when generating the control, the proposed LQG control, based on a stochastic modal model, overcomes the above limitation by estimating the states using a KBF. This filter utilizes noisy partial output information, and is more suitable for experimental investigations since it corresponds to a more realistic approach.

Figures 4 to 15 show very efficient vibration suppressions, although all the states are estimated by using three sensors, and these positive simulation results can motivate to set up cheap test-beds for deeper investigations on multilink flexible manipulators, based on the combination of hardware platforms with code implementations of the strategies proposed herein. Figure 12.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3 θ4] = [45° −60° 90°] − EX1). Figure 13.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3 θ4] = [45° −60° 90°] − EX2). Figure 14.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° −90° −90°] − EX1). Figure 15.
Vibration control for the two-link manipulator ([θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° −90° −90°] − EX2).

Finally, as an example, Figure 16 shows the control spillover effect when active vibration control is performed on the 4-link manipulator for the posture [θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° -90° -90°]. From the figure, it is clear how control inputs excite residual modes causing a structural response (thicker line) which differs from that expected (thinner line). As explained in Section 5.1, it is possible to considerably reduce the spillover phenomenon by modifying the performance index of the LQR problem through a quadratic term depending on the external disturbance matrix Br_ctrl of the residual subsystem. The resulting effect of such an effective change is shown in Figure 17. Figure 16.
Control spillover ([θ2 θ3 θ4] = [90° −90° −90°] − EX1). Figure 17.
Spillover reduction.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: A self-contained work regarding planar multilink flexible manipulators has been presented herein.The authors have focused their efforts to develop a complete tool, allowing the vibrations in such robotic structures to be analyzed and controlled. The objective has been pursued through a system mode solution to the PDEs for a general multilink manipulator. To predict real systems more accurately, the mixed axial-bending problem has been formulated and the true system mode eigenfrequencies and eigenfunctions have been produced by naturally coupling axial forces, shear forces and bending moments at joints. A block matrix formulation for the posture-dependent eigenvalue problem has been derived, where a one-to-one correspondence between blocks and links is established.

Exact modal data have been used to solve the forced vibration problem of flexible manipulators when excited by arbitrary loads in their blocked configuration. The orthogonality conditions have been derived by proofs and a modal decoupling strategy has been presented.

Knowledge of the modal equations has allowed the derivation of a state space representation of the reduced modal space, useful for investigating active vibration control strategies. Optimal control theory has been employed to develop a vibration suppression strategy based on the use of collocated sensor/actuator pairs, which can represent ideal piezoelectric pairs. An LQG controller with a KBF has been proposed. Moreover, an optimal criterion for the placement of the collocated sensor/actuator pairs on the multilink manipulator and a feasible solution for the spillover reduction have been given.
The validity of our analysis has been verified through numerical studies. The analysis results can be applied to general flexible structures in combination with axial and bending vibration.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

app.title: Appendix A. Blocks of the characteristic matrix (24)
Appendix B. Proof of orthogonality conditions (30) and (31)

sec.p: Boundary conditions (6) to (15) can be rewritten for the jth system mode shape in the form separated in space as follows

At xi = Li or xi+1=0, i=1, 2,…, n−1 (B.2)V ij '(Li)-V i+1,j '(0)=0 (B.3)V ij(Li)sinθi+1+Uij(Li)cosθi+1-Ui+1,j(0)=0 (B.4)V ij(Li)cosθi+1-Uij(Li)sinθi+1-V i+1,j(0)=0 (B.5)EiIiV ij ″(Li)-ωj 2Ji+1V ij '(Li)-Ei+1Ii+1V i+1,j ″(0)=0 (B.6) (B.7)
At xn = Ln (B.8)EnInV nj ″(Ln)-ωj 2JPV nj '(Ln)=0 (B.9)EnSnU nj '(Ln)-ωj 2MPU nj(Ln)=0 (B.10)-EnInV nj ″'(Ln)-ωj 2MPV nj(Ln)=0
From equations (18) and (19), valid for each link, it can be written that (B.11) where k refers to the kth system mode shape.
Applying the integration by part, the right hand side of equation (B.11) becomes (B.12)
Now, imposing the boundary conditions (B.1) to (B.10), the term (B.12) can be written as (B.13)
From this last expression, equation (B.11) becomes (B.14)
Similarly, if we exchange j and k, it becomes (B.15)
By subtracting equation (B.15) from equation (B.14) we have (B.16)
Since ωj2 ≠ ωk2 for j ≠ k, the terms multiplied by (ωj2 − ωk2) must be zero, which concludes the proof of equation (30).

For the proof of equation (31), we observe that equations (18) and (19) result, for the jth mode, into the following expressions (B.17)miU ij(xi)=-(EiSiωj 2)U ij ″(xi) (B.18)miV ij(xi)=(EiIiωj 2)V ij IV(xi)
By inserting these last relations into equation (30), theorthogonality condition (31) is directly proven.

By inserting term (C.22) into equation (C.14) and ordering the resulting equation, we obtain the dynamics of the modal coordinate gj(t) as expressed by equation (35), with the generalized quantities MGj, KGj and FGj(t) given by equations (32) to (34), thus concluding the proof.
